subject: Re: [junit] Testing getXXX( ) and setXXX( ) methods by creating protected variables
msgSnippet: If I were to test get / set methods, I would 1. make the state variable protected (as oppose to private) 2. have my test classes in the same package
messageBody:
If I were to test get / set methods, I would

1. make the state variable "protected" (as oppose to private)
2. have my test classes in the same package structure (to allows access)
3. set the variables directly in a test and assert the get / set methods

1. Why protected?

There is a trade off between exposing your class and letting others have limited access.

2. Why same package structure?

To take advantage of the protected nature of the variable. A test class can now directly manipulate a variable to assert the proper workings of the set / get classes.

3. Why set directly?

Set the variable directly, then assert against the get and / or set methods.


I provided a brief example at the end of this email.

As a quick preference I rarely just create "get" and "set" methods because I have a particular state variable. I feel that it done primarily because everyone seems to do it as oppose to doing it for functional reasons.

If anything, I will only allow for get methods to avoid corrupting my object. In general, I prefer to wait until there is a functional need to have get and set methods, otherwise I keep the variable "private" and completely hidden for others not use, or see.

andrew f

````````````````````````````

A brief example of how I test get / set methods.

+ /src/main
org.blah.util.MyClass.java

protected int i_;
public int getI() { ... }
public void setI(int i) { ... }

+ /src/testsuite
org.blah.util.MyClassTest.java

MyClass myc;

public void setUp() {
myc = new MyClass();
}

public void test_setA() {
int expected = 1;
myc.i_ = expected;
int actual = myc.getI();
assertEquals(expected,actual);
}

Subject: [junit] Testing getXXX( ) and setXXX( ) methods


Hi,

I am trying to answer the following question for myself -
"What is the best approach for testing get/set methods ?"

I have my approach outlined below and would welcome comments.

Take the example :

public class Car {
private String _color;

public String getColor() {
return _color
}

public void setColor(String color$) {
_color = color$;
}

}

To me, the 'best' approach seems to be the following :

1. Create an inner class CarTest that will test this class.

2. in the setUp() method, create a new Car obect and set the
internal field to the "test" value. i.e. set the field values
directly.

3. Testing the get method

Call the get method and make sure the 'test' value is correctly
returned by the get method.

4. Testing the set method

Call the set method with a new value.
Check the internal field and verify that the value is the
one specified via set().

I'm interested in opinions/suggestions.

Thanks,

Raju
